channel.title: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?
channel.description:
I don't know to do something like this but I wanted that if a users IP address is in my MySQL database then it would allow the user to view page otherwise redirect them to another webpage if they try to visit the page or show a blank page.
I have like 0 knowledge of php and js :(

item.title: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?
item.dc:creator: @Zeanr Zeanr
item.description:
@Zeanr wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:11, topic:522688”][quote author=Zeanr link=topic=641185.msg4328570#msg4328570 date=1373339443]

$ip = $_SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR'];

if($ip == '0.0.0.0'){
}
else{
header('http://redirect_page_link_here');
}

That simplifies everything, doesn’t it? I used this script before to hide certain member’s pages.
[/quote]He did ask specifically to check if it’s in a database.[/quote]

I understand that, but for me, the way I said would be much easier… wouldn’t it?

@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Zeanr, post:10, topic:522688”][code=php]
$ip = $_SERVER[‘REMOTE_ADDR’];

if($ip == ‘0.0.0.0’){
}
else{
header(‘http://redirect_page_link_here’);
}
[/code]

That simplifies everything, doesn’t it? I used this script before to hide certain member’s pages.[/quote]He did ask specifically to check if it’s in a database.

item.title: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

Doing this with PHP is the way to go, not through JS. When Wikipedia had their “blackout” they just used JS to hide content, but disabling JS made the content visible again.

[/quote]
Thanks for the advice, will remember that next time

I imagine Arcik is only using it so a select number of people can access her site or whatever so speed isn’t too important, so I whipped it up pretty quick, but that’s good to know.[/quote]Yeah I doubt the speed would be very noticeable in small cases or on sites without many concurrent users, but I think it’d be a good habit to get into nonetheless.

item.title: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:6, topic:522688”][quote=SilentCJ] $query = "SELECT * FROM ips WHERE allowed = '$remote_ip'"; $result = mysqli_query($con, $query); if(mysqli_num_rows($result) > 0) {[/quote]
If I remember correctly, it would be faster to use:

As a query, then simply use mysqli_result in PHP to check if it’s greater than one, rather than using PHP to check the row count. If you’re dealing with a query that could potentially return a lot of large results, it’s really wasteful for MySQL to send them to PHP just to have PHP count them. Not only that but the SQL engine can make further optimizations and just serve its own indexed size that it computes internally.

stackoverflow.com

Semaphore in Python

python, semaphore
Zeh on 10:46AM - 20 Mar 18

Thanks for the advice, will remember that next time

I imagine Arcik is only using it so a select number of people can access her site or whatever so speed isn’t too important, so I whipped it up pretty quick, but that’s good to know.

Read full topic
item.source: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?

item.title: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[code=php] $query = "SELECT * FROM ips WHERE allowed = '$remote_ip'"; $result = mysqli_query($con, $query); if(mysqli_num_rows($result) > 0) {[/code]
If I remember correctly, it would be faster to use: [code=sql]SELECT COUNT(*) FROM ips WHERE allowed = "127.0.0.1"[/code] As a query, then simply use mysqli_result in PHP to check if it's greater than one, rather than using PHP to check the row count. If you're dealing with a query that could potentially return a lot of large results, it's really wasteful for MySQL to send them to PHP just to have PHP count them. Not only that but the SQL engine can make further optimizations and just serve its own indexed size that it computes internally.
stackoverflow.com

SQL & PHP - Which is faster mysql_num_rows() or 'select count()'?

php, sql, performance
asked by Joel on 11:46PM - 20 Mar 10

Read full topic

item.title: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Even if your syntax was right it wouldn’t work I’m afraid
You don’t really need a banned column as such, unless you explicitly wish to ban individual IP’s. Simply specify the IP’s that you want allowed in the allowed column and you’re all set.

Not tested or anything but should be fine. I know you have no concern for bad code but I advise using mysqli functions over mysql, they will be removed completely within a few years.

    $con = mysqli_connect('localhost', 'root', 'password', 'database');
    $remote_ip = $_SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR'];
    $query = "SELECT * FROM ips WHERE allowed = '$remote_ip'";
    $result = mysqli_query($con, $query);
    if(mysqli_num_rows($result) > 0) {
    	echo 'Allowed';
    }
    else {
    	header('Location: www.example.com');
    	/*
			Could also set a session variable to store a message to display
			to the user on the new page
    	*/
    }
    mysqli_close($con);

Read full topic
item.source: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?

item.title: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

*Removed my message and wrote it again

I got everything work expect grabbing IP from database.
Here’s an example of how it’s all done:

database: ‘database’
username: ‘root’
password: ‘password’

then there’s a table called ‘ips’ with two columns ‘allowed’ and ‘banned’

if (allowed) { echo 'allowed'; } else echo 'banned'

This is exactly what I’m doing atm:

[code=java] mysql_connect(‘localhost’, ‘root’, ‘password’);
mysql_select_db(‘database’);

$allowed = mysql_query("SELECT allowed * FROM ips") or die(mysql_error());

if ($allowed) {
    echo 'Allowed';
} else
    echo 'You are currently banned';[/code]

Which is still causing

You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL server version for the right syntax to use near ‘FROM ips’ at line 1
unfortunately I don’t know PHP any good!

The banned column in ips is not currently being used within the code.

I have no concern for “bad code” or any legacy code mainly because idfc how its done

Read full topic

item.title: Allow people to access a web page if their IP is in a database?
item.dc:creator: @KempiScape KempiScape
item.description:
@KempiScape wrote:

<?php
$ip=$_SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR'];
$dbip='0.0.0.0'; //here you fetch from database, you can try with your own ip to see that it works

if ($ip==$dbip) {
echo 'You have permission, continue...';
} else echo 'You do not have permission.';
?>

It’s actually really easy this one, $_SERVER[‘REMOTE_ADDR’] is the users ip adress. i don’t know your database so that part you will have to figure out yourself.

Read full topic
